elements.title: Social-Proof Visual Weight in Discovery
elements.problem: At discovery, the guest encounters the platform as a stranger encountering an imagined reality for the first time. If social proof elements (review counts, activity indicators, guest testimonials) are visually subordinate to functional elements (search bars, filters, CTAs), the guest receives the wrong signal: the platform is asking them to act before it has proven that others believe in this fiction. The visual hierarchy must weight social proof heavily enough to establish the myth's credibility at first glance.
elements.solution: Apply a visual treatment that elevates social proof to primary visual weight in the discovery viewport. Aggregate trust numbers (e.g., '2,400+ verified stays') use the serif heading typeface at a prominent size with accent color. Testimonial cards sit alongside listing cards in the browse grid, not relegated to a separate testimonials section. Activity indicators (recently booked, new listing) use the signal-info color on accent-light backgrounds to stand out without competing with the primary content.

evidence.quote: Telling effective stories is not easy. The difficulty lies not in telling the story, but in convincing everyone else to believe it.
evidence.insight: Visual hierarchy is how the platform 'tells its story' — the elements with the most visual weight communicate what the platform most wants the stranger to believe. Social proof must visually outweigh functional UI to convey 'others believe in this.'

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first.
evidence.insight: The visual system must prioritize evidence (real listings, real trust signals) over interface chrome. This means social proof elements carry more visual weight than search controls at first viewport.

new_tokens_needed: activity-pulse: a subtle dot animation for 'recently active' indicators — 8px diameter, signal-info color, 2s pulse cycle

elements.contrast_requirements: Trust aggregate numbers must meet WCAG AA against accent-light background (contrast ratio >= 4.5:1). Activity indicators must meet AA against surface backgrounds.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Social proof aggregate > listing cards > search controls > secondary navigation. The trust number is the single largest typographic element in the first viewport.
elements.brand_alignment: The serif typeface on trust numbers evokes authority and permanence — the platform's 'myth' is not new or experimental, it is established and believed by many. This aligns with the brand's sophisticated, trust-forward positioning.

elements.title: Gossip-Layer Card Visual Treatment
elements.problem: Listing cards must visually support a three-layer gossip structure (glance, scan, deep) without appearing cluttered or overwhelming at any layer. The current flat visual treatment gives equal visual weight to all data points, making it harder for the guest to quickly extract the trust-relevant information (host verification, availability, responsiveness) from the descriptive information (amenities, size).
elements.solution: Apply distinct visual treatments to each information layer on the card: (1) Glance layer — photo occupies 60% of card height, price uses semibold sans in ink color, neighborhood label uses a muted chip style; (2) Scan layer (hover) — the card elevates with shadow-md, revealing a secondary row with availability dot, response time in ink-muted text, and a subtle save icon; (3) Trust badge — a small verification chip in accent color appears at the photo overlay corner. The visual language distinguishes between always-visible data (strong ink, larger type) and progressive data (muted ink, smaller type, revealed on hover).

evidence.quote: Reliable information about who could be trusted meant that small bands could expand into larger bands, and Sapiens could develop tighter and more sophisticated types of cooperation.
evidence.insight: Visual layering of gossip information mirrors how trust builds in Sapiens social groups — from surface signals (appearance) to deeper knowledge (reputation, behavior). The card's visual layers should follow this progression.

evidence.quote: Richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators, neighborhood labels, and quick actions — all without leaving the search grid.
evidence.insight: The visual system must support progressive reveal within the card boundary. Hover state is not decorative — it is a distinct information layer with its own visual language.

new_tokens_needed: card-hover-elevation: shadow-md transition with easing.out over 200ms
photo-counter-overlay: semi-transparent ink background (rgba(26,23,20,0.6)) with white text, positioned bottom-right of photo area

elements.contrast_requirements: Verification badge text (#ffffff) on accent background (#2d5a3d) must meet WCAG AA (ratio ~8:1, passes). Price text (ink) on surface must meet AAA. Photo counter overlay text must meet AA against the semi-transparent background.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Photo > price > neighborhood > trust badge > hover details. The photo is the primary visual element (60% of card area), followed by price as the strongest typographic element, then neighborhood as contextual anchor.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm surface colors and organic shadow transitions convey approachability — the guest is browsing homes, not shopping for products. The muted chip treatment for neighborhood labels grounds each listing in a real place, reinforcing the dual-reality bridge.

elements.title: Trust-First Listing Detail Visual Hierarchy
elements.problem: The listing detail page must visually prioritize trust evidence over listing description, because the guest's primary intent is stranger-assessment, not feature comparison. If the photo gallery, host identity block, and review summary do not dominate the first viewport, the guest's trust-evaluation is delayed and dropout risk increases.
elements.solution: Design the listing detail with a clear visual hierarchy: (1) Photo gallery spans full width at the top, with a counter chip and fullscreen affordance; (2) Immediately below, a host identity row with circular host photo (48px), name in semibold, verification badge, and response rate — this row uses accent-light background to visually separate it from the content below; (3) Review summary line (e.g., '4.8 stars from 12 reviews') in serif typeface at medium size, with a 'read all' link; (4) Below the trust zone, listing details begin in standard body typography. The trust zone occupies the first ~40% of the initial viewport.

evidence.quote: Trade cannot exist without trust, and it is very difficult to trust strangers. The global trade network of today is based on our trust in such fictional entities as the dollar, the Federal Reserve Bank, and the totemic trademarks of corporations.
evidence.insight: On the listing detail, the host identity block and review summary are the platform's 'totemic trademarks' — the fictional entities that must be visually prominent because they are the basis for the stranger's willingness to trade (cooperate).

evidence.quote: Even if a user loves what they see on the card, they'll still open the listing before committing — to check host reviews, credibility, full photos. The jump from card to proposal skips steps people naturally need.
evidence.insight: The listing detail page exists to serve the trust-evaluation instinct. Its visual treatment must make trust evidence the most visually salient content, not an afterthought below the description.

new_tokens_needed: host-avatar-ring: 2px solid accent color ring around host photo to visually anchor identity
trust-zone-divider: 1px border-strong line separating the trust section from listing details

elements.contrast_requirements: Host name on accent-light background must meet WCAG AA. Review star color (signal-warn) on white/surface must meet AA for icons (3:1 ratio minimum). All body text meets AAA against surface backgrounds.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Photo gallery > host identity + trust signals > review summary > listing details > action bar. The trust zone (host + reviews) occupies more visual real estate than any single content section.
elements.brand_alignment: Using serif for review summary and listing headings creates a sense of permanence and authority — this is not a disposable listing, it is a home. The accent-light background on the host identity row creates a warm, inviting zone that humanizes the stranger.

elements.title: Ceremonial Proposal Confirmation Visual
elements.problem: The proposal submission and acceptance are ritual moments that transform a negotiable fiction into a binding agreement. If these moments look identical to any other button click in the product, the guest does not feel the weight of the transition — the ritual fails to mark the cooperation threshold. Conversely, if the visual treatment is too heavy or intimidating, it creates last-moment anxiety that increases abandonment.
elements.solution: Design the proposal confirmation and acceptance moments with a distinct visual treatment that differs from standard UI interactions: (1) The proposal summary card uses surface-warm background with a subtle border-strong frame, creating a 'document' feel; (2) The submit button uses the gradient-purple-button treatment reserved exclusively for binding actions; (3) On submission success, a brief full-viewport overlay with a check animation in accent color and a serif confirmation message ('Your proposal has been sent') marks the moment before transitioning to the status view. The acceptance 'Yes, Proceed' button uses the same gradient treatment for visual consistency across binding-action moments.

evidence.quote: Once the lawyer had performed all the right rituals and pronounced all the necessary spells and oaths, millions of upright French citizens behaved as if the Peugeot company really existed.
evidence.insight: Ritual moments need distinct visual treatment because they mark the transition from fiction to binding reality. The visual system must make these moments feel different from ordinary interactions — ceremonial, clear, and memorable.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal — clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent — activates the host to respond.
evidence.insight: The proposal summary card must visually communicate completeness and clarity — every term visible, every cost transparent — so that the 'ritual' succeeds in creating a strong shared fiction between guest and host.

new_tokens_needed: binding-action-gradient: reserved gradient treatment used exclusively for proposal submission and lease acceptance — visual consistency across all 'ritual' moments
success-overlay-duration: 2 seconds visible before auto-transitioning to status view

elements.contrast_requirements: Submit button text (#ffffff) on gradient-purple background must meet WCAG AA (midpoint ~#6384DC, ratio >= 4.5:1). Summary term labels on surface-warm must meet AA. Success confirmation text on overlay must meet AAA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Summary card > submit button > secondary actions (edit, cancel). The summary card is the central visual element — it is the 'decorated document' of the ritual. The submit button is visually distinct from all other buttons in the product through its exclusive gradient treatment.
elements.brand_alignment: The gradient-purple treatment for binding actions creates a consistent visual language for commitment moments throughout the product. The surface-warm summary card with border-strong framing evokes a physical document — appropriate for a moment that creates a real-world agreement between two strangers.

elements.title: Living-Map Contextual Layer Styling
elements.problem: The map must visually transition from a utilitarian location tool to a living representation of neighborhood reality. Currently, pin markers on a standard map tile do not convey the intersubjective sense of place — the 'mood' that the user stories identify as the real purpose of the map. The visual treatment must add contextual layers (transit, landmarks, activity) without overwhelming the primary listing-location function.
elements.solution: Apply a layered visual treatment to the map: (1) Base layer — custom map tiles with muted, warm-toned colors that align with the brand palette (bg and bg-deep tones); (2) Listing pins — circular markers in accent color with a subtle shadow-sm, sized to indicate relative availability or relevance; (3) Context layer — transit icons in signal-info color at reduced opacity (60%), landmark labels in ink-muted text, walkability radius as a soft accent-light circle; (4) Activity layer (future) — subtle pulse animations on recently-active listings. The contextual layers use lower visual weight than listing pins, maintaining clear functional hierarchy.

evidence.quote: Ever since the Cognitive Revolution, Sapiens has thus been living in a dual reality. On the one hand, the objective reality of rivers, trees and lions; and on the other hand, the imagined reality of gods, nations and corporations.
evidence.insight: The map bridges dual reality: objective geography and imagined neighborhood identity. The visual treatment must layer the imagined (community, livability, mood) on top of the objective (streets, coordinates) using distinct but harmonious visual languages.

evidence.quote: Transit stops, landmarks, real-time context — this is about mood, not just utility. The feeling that something is happening.
evidence.insight: The map's visual treatment must convey liveliness and activity — not through loud colors or heavy decoration, but through warm tones, subtle contextual markers, and the sense of a populated place.

colors.map_tile_land: tokens.colors.bg (#f6f4f0) — warm base for custom tiles

new_tokens_needed: map-warm-tile-palette: custom Mapbox/Leaflet style using bg, bg-deep, and border tones for a warm, branded map that does not clash with the product's color system
listing-pin-cluster: when pins overlap at zoom level, cluster using accent color at 80% opacity with white count text

elements.contrast_requirements: Listing pins (accent on map background) must be distinguishable at 3:1 minimum contrast. Transit icons at 60% opacity must remain visible against map tile backgrounds. Selected pin state must be visually distinct from default (size + brightness change).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Listing pins > transit context > landmarks > walkability radius > map base. The map exists to serve listing discovery, so listing markers always dominate; contextual layers support without competing.
elements.brand_alignment: Warm-toned custom map tiles extend the brand's visual language into cartographic space. The muted, organic palette reinforces the feeling of browsing real neighborhoods in a real city — not a sterile data visualization.

elements.title: Move-In House Manual Visual Treatment
elements.problem: The House Manual is the guest's reference document for navigating cooperation with a stranger in a shared physical space. If it visually resembles a terms-of-service page (dense text, no structure, legal tone), the guest will not read it. If it looks too casual, it fails to convey the seriousness of the cooperation norms. The visual treatment must strike a balance between approachable and authoritative — a 'law book' that feels like a welcome guide.
elements.solution: Design the House Manual as a structured, card-based document: each section (Arrival, Rules, Space Guide, Neighborhood) is a distinct card on surface-warm background with a serif section heading and icon. Within each card, information items are presented as concise bullet points in sans body text. Critical items (check-in code, emergency contact, key return procedure) use a signal-info-bg highlight bar to visually elevate them above standard items. The overall layout uses generous spacing (xl between sections) and avoids dense text blocks.

evidence.quote: But once the threshold of 150 individuals is crossed, things can no longer work that way. You cannot run a division with thousands of soldiers the same way you run a platoon. Successful family businesses usually face a crisis when they grow larger.
evidence.insight: Beyond intimate acquaintance, cooperation requires codified rules. The House Manual's visual treatment must convey 'these are the norms we share' with enough authority to be taken seriously, but enough warmth to feel collaborative rather than imposed.

evidence.quote: The park analogy holds — you check availability before committing.
evidence.insight: Guests naturally seek preparation before commitment. The House Manual's visual treatment must invite reading and reference, not discourage it. Structured cards with clear headings support the guest's preparatory instinct.

new_tokens_needed: manual-section-icon: 24px monochrome icons for each section (key, rules, home, map) in ink-muted color

elements.contrast_requirements: Section headings (ink on surface-warm) meet WCAG AAA. Critical item text on signal-info-bg meets AA. Body text (ink-soft on surface-warm) meets AA minimum.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Section headings > critical highlighted items > standard items > section icons. The serif headings create clear wayfinding; the info-bg highlights draw attention to must-know items within each section.
elements.brand_alignment: The card-based manual design with serif headings mirrors the brand's warm, sophisticated tone. Surface-warm backgrounds and generous spacing create a 'home' feeling appropriate for a document about living in someone's space.
